investment_tools package

Submodules

investment_tools.company module

class investment_tools.company.Company(ticker: str, api_key: str, data: str = 'online', period: str = 'annual', limit: int = 20, verbose: bool = False)[source]

Bases: object

Class representing a company and its financial analysis

Parameters

  • ticker (str) – The stock symbol representing the company

  • api_key (str) – API key for accessing financial data from a data source

  • data (str, optional) – Source of data either from ‘online’ (default) or ‘offline’

  • period (str, optional) – Financial period to use for the analysis either ‘annual’ (default) or ‘quarterly’

  • limit (int, optional) – The number of financial periods to include in the analysis (default is 20)

  • verbose (bool, optional) – If True, verbose output will be printed during analysis (default is False)

ticker

The stock symbol representing the company

Type

str

period

Financial period used for the analysis

Type

str

metrics

Dictionary of financial metrics for the company

Type

dict

trends

List of plots showing the trend of the financial metrics over time

Type

list of plot objects

Methods: __init__(self, ticker, api_key, data=’online’, period=’annual’, limit=20, verbose=False):

Initializes a new instance of the Company class.

Parameters: ticker (str): The stock symbol representing the company api_key (str): API key for accessing financial data from a data source data (str, optional): Source of data either from ‘online’ (default) or ‘offline’ period (str, optional): Financial period to use for the analysis either ‘annual’ (default) or ‘quarterly’ limit (int, optional): The number of financial periods to include in the analysis (default is 20) verbose (bool, optional): If True, verbose output will be printed during analysis (default is False)

recommendation(self) -> Dict[str, dict]:

Builds a recommendation for the company based on its financial metrics.

Returns: A dictionary with the keys being the metrics and the values being another dictionary with ‘score’

and ‘strength’ keys.

get_modifier(self, metric: str) -> int:

Returns a modifier based on whether the metric is related to debt.

Parameters: metric (str): The name of the financial metric.

Returns: 1 if the metric is not related to debt, -1 otherwise.

get_copy_of_df_column(self, header: str) -> pd.Series:

Returns a copy of a column of data for a given metric.

Parameters: header (str): The name of the financial metric.

Returns: A copy of the column of data for the given metric.

get_r2_val(metrics: pd.Series) -> float:

Returns the R-squared value for a given series of metrics.

Parameters: metrics (pd.Series): A series of metrics.

Returns: The R-squared value for the given series of metrics.

score(self, metric: str) -> Tuple[int, int]:

Computes the score for a given metric.

Parameters: metric (str): The name of the financial metric.

Returns: A tuple containing the growth score and the stability score for the given metric.

score_mean_growth(self, mean_growth: float) -> int:

Computes the growth score for a given mean growth rate.

Parameters: mean_growth (float): The mean growth rate.

Returns: The growth score for the given mean growth rate.

score_trend_strength(r2: float) -> int:

Calculates the trend strength score based on the R^2 value of a metric.

Args: r2 (float): The R^2 value of a metric.

Returns: int: The trend strength score.

eval_(scores: Dict[str, dict]) -> bool:

Evaluates the overall recommendation for the company based on the scores for each metric.

Args: scores (Dict[str, dict]): A dictionary of scores for each metric.

Returns: bool: True if the recommendation is positive, False otherwise.

print_charts() -> None:

Prints the trend charts for each metric.

Returns: None

export() -> None:

Exports the financial trend charts to disk as a pdf file. Also exports key findings based on the analysis.

export() → None[source]

The export() method exports the financial trend charts to a PDF file.

Returns: None.

print_charts() → None[source]

Prints the trend charts for the company’s financial metrics.

If the charts have already been printed, this method does nothing.

Returns: None

class investment_tools.evaluation.StandardEvaluation(ticker: str, api_key: str, metrics: pandas.core.series.Series, financial_data: investment_tools.financial_data.FinancialData)[source]

Bases: object

A class to standardize and evaluate the financial data for a given company.

ticker

The stock symbol for the company.

Type

str

api_key

The API key for the financial data provider.

Type

str

metrics

A Pandas Series of financial data for the company.

Type

pd.Series

_financial_data

A Pandas DataFrame of the financial data for the company.

Type

pd.DataFrame

_scoring_metrics

A list of financial metrics used to calculate scores.

Type

List[str]

standard_scores_dict

A dictionary containing scores and strengths for each financial metric.

Type

Dict[str, dict]

standard_outcome

A boolean indicating whether the company has favorable financial metrics based on the provided scores.

Type

bool

Returns a list of financial metrics used to calculate scores.

standard_eval(self) → bool[source]

Determines if the company has favorable financial metrics based on the provided scores.

calculate_mean_growth_from_series_trend(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, span: Optional[int] = None) → float[source]

Calculates the mean growth rate of a financial metric over a specified span of time.

Parameters

  • df (pd.DataFrame) – A pandas DataFrame containing the financial metric data.

  • span (int, optional) – The number of periods over which to calculate the growth rate. If not provided, calculates the growth rate over the full length of the DataFrame.

Returns

The mean growth rate of the financial metric over the specified span of time.

Return type

float

create_scoring_metrics_results_dict(scoring_metrics: List[str]) → Dict[str, dict][source]

Creates and returns a dictionary of scores and strengths for the provided list of scoring metrics.

Args: scoring_metrics (List[str]): A list of the scoring metrics to create the dictionary for.

Returns: Dict[str, dict]: A dictionary of scores and strengths for the provided scoring metrics.

get_copy_of_df_column(header: str) → pandas.core.series.Series[source]

Returns a copy of a pandas Series for a given column header in the calculated metrics DataFrame.

Args: header (str): The header of the column to return.

Returns: pd.Series: A copy of the column as a pandas Series with any missing values removed.

get_modifier(metric: str) → int[source]

Returns a modifier based on the provided metric. If the metric name contains ‘debt’, the modifier is -1. Otherwise, it is 1.

Args: metric (str): The name of the metric.

Returns: int: The modifier to be used in calculations.

get_r2_val(metrics: pandas.core.series.Series) → float[source]

Calculates and returns the R-squared value of a linear regression model for the given Pandas series of metrics.

Args: metrics (pd.Series): A Pandas series containing the metric values.

Returns: float: The R-squared value of the linear regression model.

get_scoring_metrics() → List[str][source]

Returns a list of financial metrics to score.

Returns

A list of strings representing financial metrics.

Return type

List[str]

get_slope_and_intercept(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame) → Tuple[float, float][source]

Calculates the slope and intercept of a linear regression line for the given pandas DataFrame.

Parameters

df (pd.DataFrame) – A pandas DataFrame containing the data to calculate the slope and intercept from.

Returns

A tuple containing the calculated slope and intercept as floats with rounding to 4 decimal places.

Return type

Tuple[float, float]

score_mean_growth(mean_growth: float) → int[source]

Scores the mean growth of a metric based on the following ranges:

  • 0: <= 0.05

  • 1: <= 0.10

  • 2: <= 0.15

  • 3: <= 0.20

  • 4: > 0.20

Parameters

mean_growth (float) – The mean growth of a financial metric

Returns

The score for the mean growth of the metric based on the above ranges.

Return type

int

score_single_metric(metric: str) → Tuple[int, int][source]

Calculates the growth score and the trend stability score of the given financial metric.

Args: metric (str): The name of the financial metric to score.

Returns: A tuple containing the growth score and the trend stability score. The growth score is an integer value between 0 and 4, indicating the mean growth rate of the metric. The trend stability score is an integer value between 0 and 4, indicating the strength of the trend of the metric.

score_trend_strength(r2: float) → int[source]

Calculate the trend strength score for a financial metric.

Parameters

r2 (float) – The coefficient of determination (R^2) of the trend line.

Returns

The trend strength score for the metric, from 0 to 4.

Return type

int

standard_eval() → bool[source]

Determines if the company has favorable financial metrics based on the provided scores.

Parameters

None –

Returns

True if the company has favorable financial metrics based on the provided scores, False otherwise.

Return type

bool

sum_of_scoring_metric_dict_scores(scores_dict: Dict[str, dict]) → int[source]

Sums the scores for each metric in a given dictionary of scores and strengths.

Parameters

scores_dict (Dict[str, dict]) – A dictionary of scores and strengths for various financial metrics.

Returns

The sum of the scores for each metric in the given dictionary. If a score is NaN, it is treated as 0.

Return type

int

total_score_to_bool(total_score: int, threshold: Optional[int] = None) → bool[source]

Determines if the total score of the scoring metrics meets the threshold.

Parameters

  • total_score (int) – The total score of the scoring metrics.

  • threshold (int, optional) – The threshold to meet or exceed. Defaults to 2*len(self._scoring_metrics).

Returns

True if the total score meets or exceeds the threshold, False otherwise.

Return type

bool

investment_tools.financial_data module

class investment_tools.financial_data.FinancialData(ticker: str, api_key: str = '', data: str = 'local', period: str = 'annual', limit: int = 120)[source]

Bases: object

A class for retrieving and storing financial data for a given stock ticker.

ticker

The stock ticker symbol.

Type

str

api_key

An optional API key to access financial data.

Type

str, optional

data

Specifies whether to retrieve data from an online source or a local data store.

Type

str

period

The time period for which data is retrieved, either “annual” or “quarterly”.

Type

str

limit

The maximum number of financial statements to retrieve.

Type

int

balance_sheets

The balance sheet data for the stock.

Type

pandas.DataFrame

income_statements

The income statement data for the stock.

Type

pandas.DataFrame

cash_flow_statements

The cash flow statement data for the stock.

Type

pandas.DataFrame

reported_key_metrics

The reported key metric data for the stock.

Type

pandas.DataFrame

stock_price_data

The stock price data for the stock.

Type

pandas.DataFrame

Raises

AssertionError – If invalid input is provided for data or period attributes.

Cross-checks reported financial metrics against calculated financial metrics and returns the fractional errors.

analyse() → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame[source]

Analyzes the financial data and calculates a variety of financial ratios.

Returns

A DataFrame containing the calculated financial ratios.

Return type

pd.DataFrame

The following ratio types are calculated using financial data from the associated FinancialData object:

  • Stock evaluation ratios

  • Profitability ratios

  • Debt and interest ratios

  • Liquidity ratios

  • Efficiency ratios

  • Metric growth

assert_non_null_frame(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame) → None[source]

Raises an AssertionError if any column in the input DataFrame is completely null.

Parameters

df (pandas.DataFrame) – A pandas DataFrame.

Raises

AssertionError – If any column in df is completely null.

concat_debt_interest_ratios(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame) → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame[source]

Concatenates debt and interest ratios to the given DataFrame.

Parameters

df (pd.DataFrame) – DataFrame to which debt and interest ratios will be added.

Returns

DataFrame with added debt and interest ratios.

Return type

pd.DataFrame

Calculates the following debt and interest ratios:

  • Interest coverage

  • Fixed charge coverage

  • Debt to total capitalization ratio

  • Total debt ratio

All ratios are calculated using financial data from the associated FinancialData object.

concat_efficiency_ratios(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame) → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame[source]

Concatenates efficiency ratios to the given DataFrame.

Parameters

df (pd.DataFrame) – DataFrame to which efficiency ratios will be added.

Returns

DataFrame with added efficiency ratios.

Return type

pd.DataFrame

Calculates the following efficiency ratios:

  • Total asset turnover

  • Inventory to sales ratio

  • Inventory turnover ratio

  • Inventory turnover in days

  • Accounts receivable to sales ratio

  • Receivables turnover

  • Receivables turnover in days

All ratios are calculated using financial data from the associated FinancialData object.

concat_liquidity_ratios(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame) → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame[source]

Concatenates liquidity ratios to the given DataFrame.

Parameters

df (pd.DataFrame) – DataFrame to which liquidity ratios will be added.

Returns

DataFrame with added liquidity ratios.

Return type

pd.DataFrame

Calculates the following liquidity ratios:

  • Current ratio

  • Quick ratio

  • Cash ratio

All ratios are calculated using financial data from the associated FinancialData object.

concat_metric_growth(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame) → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame[source]

Concatenates growth rates for specified metrics to the given DataFrame.

Parameters

df (pd.DataFrame) – DataFrame to which growth rates will be added.

Returns

DataFrame with added growth rates.

Return type

pd.DataFrame

Calculates the percentage growth rate for the following metrics over a one year or four quarter period:

  • Earnings per share (EPS)

  • Return on equity (ROE)

  • Cash per share

  • Price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio (average close)

  • Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) ratio

  • Return on invested capital (ROIC)

  • Net profit margin

  • Return on assets (ROA)

  • Debt to total capitalization ratio

  • Total debt ratio

All growth rates are calculated using financial data from the associated FinancialData object.

concat_profitability_ratios(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame) → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame[source]

Concatenates profitability ratios to the given DataFrame.

Parameters

df (pd.DataFrame) – DataFrame to which profitability ratios will be added.

Returns

DataFrame with added profitability ratios.

Return type

pd.DataFrame

Calculates the following profitability ratios:

  • Gross profit margin

  • Operating profit margin

  • Pretax profit margin

  • Net profit margin

  • Return on invested capital (ROIC)

  • Return on equity (ROE)

  • Return on Assets (ROA)

All ratios are calculated using financial data from the associated FinancialData object.

concat_stock_eval_ratios(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame) → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame[source]

Calculate and concatenate stock evaluation ratios to the given DataFrame.

Parameters

df (pandas.DataFrame) – The DataFrame to concatenate the calculated metrics to.

Returns

The resulting DataFrame containing the calculated metrics.

Return type

pandas.DataFrame

Calculates the following stock evaluation ratios:

  • Earnings per share (EPS)

  • Diluted earnings per share (EPSDiluted)

  • Price to earnings ratio (PE) for high, low, and average closing stock prices

  • Book value per share

  • Dividend payout ratio

  • Dividend yield for low, high, and average closing stock prices

  • EBITDA ratio

  • Cash per share

  • shareholderEquityPerShare

All ratios are calculated using financial data from the associated FinancialData object.

cross_check_metric_calculations() → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame[source]

Calculates the fractional error between reported metrics and those calculated by the program for a selection of key metrics. If verbose is set to False, returns None.

Returns

DataFrame containing the fractional errors for each metric.

Return type

pd.DataFrame

Metrics that are cross-checked:

  • Gross profit margin

  • Operating profit margin

  • Net profit margin

  • Current ratio

  • Return on equity (ROE)

  • Return on assets (ROA)

  • Cash per share

  • Interest coverage

  • Dividend payout ratio

Fractional error is calculated as the absolute value of the difference between the calculated metric and the reported metric, divided by the calculated metric.

print_metric_errors(metric_errors: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, tolerance: float = 0.05) → None[source]

Prints the number of values for each metric that exceed the given tolerance level.

Parameters

  • metric_errors (pd.DataFrame) – Contains the fractional errors for each financial metric.

  • tolerance (float, optional) – The tolerance level for the error fraction. Defaults to 0.05.

get_linear_coeffs(x: pandas.core.series.Series, y: pandas.core.series.Series) → Tuple[float, float, float][source]

Calculate the linear regression coefficients and coefficient of determination (R-squared) for the given x and y data points.

Parameters

  • x (List[float]) – List of x data points.

  • y (List[float]) – List of y data points.

Returns

A tuple containing the slope, intercept, and R-squared value.

Return type

Tuple[float, float, float]

Calculates the linear regression coefficients for the given x and y data points using the linregress function from the scipy.stats module. The slope, intercept, and R-squared value are returned as a tuple.

  • r2 (float) – r-squared value for the linear regression.

Returns

axis object with the plotted line.

Return type

matplotlib axis

plot_metrics() → None[source]
The plot_metrics method generates plots of financial metrics for a given company. The method first

generates the necessary subplots to hold each metric type. Each metric type is then plotted on an individual axis within the metric type’s subplot. Each metric’s trend data is gathered, and its trend is plotted on the selected axis. A linear trendline is also plotted along with its corresponding R2 value. Finally, each metric type’s subplot is given a title and added to the list of plots.

Args: self (Plots): The Plots instance.

Returns: None. The method appends the generated plots to the Plots instance.

scale_y_axis(axis: matplotlib.pyplot.axis, data_str: str) → matplotlib.pyplot.axis[source]

Scales the y-axis of a given axis object based on the value of the data_str parameter.

Parameters

  • data_str (str) – A string indicating which type of data is plotted on the y-axis.

Returns

The modified axis object, with the y-axis limits set according to the data_str parameter.
